(M.G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14).proposition: COMPLAINT FOR BREACH OF THE COVENANT OF QUIET ENJOYMENT (M.G.L. c. 186, § 14)

**G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19**.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to **G.L. c. 218, § 19** and **G.L. c. 185C, § 3**, as the property in question is located in Worcester County and the rental arrangement arose within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

**G.L. c. 185C, \u00a7 3**.proposition: Jurisdiction is proper in this Court pursuant to **G.L. c. 218, § 19** and **G.L. c. 185C, § 3**, as the property in question is located in Worcester County and the rental arrangement arose within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction.

**G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14**.proposition: Pursuant to **G.L. c. 186, § 14**, every residential tenancy in Massachusetts carries with it an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, protecting tenants from serious interference with the use and enjoyment of their leased premises caused by the landlord.

*See Hemingway v. Commonwealth*, 363 Mas.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that unsanitary or unsafe conditions, especially involving vermin infestation, violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*See Hemingway v. Commonwealth*, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: This opinion (a concurrence/dissent) discusses implied warranty of habitability and the effect of State Sanitary Code violations on rent obligations, but it does not frame these issues as violations of the covenant of quiet enjoyment or focus specifically on vermin infestation as constituting such a breach. The analysis is about implying statutory-code-based duties and adjusting rent liability, not about the traditional quiet enjoyment covenant. Therefore, it does not provide direct authority for the proposition that Massachusetts courts treat unsanitary or vermin-infested conditions as violations of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*See Hemingway v. Commonwealth*, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”}

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that unsanitary or unsafe conditions, especially involving vermin infestation, violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with lack of heat and hot water and focuses on when rent abatement begins for breaches of the implied warranty of habitability. It does not discuss vermin, unsanitary conditions, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment at all; its analysis is framed in terms of the warranty of habitability and statutory sanitary code violations. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the specific proposition that vermin infestation or similar unsanitary/unsafe conditions violate the covenant of quiet enjoyment, even though it generally recognizes that substantial Sanitary Code violations make a dwelling uninhabitable.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.relevant_excerpt: “‘[T]he essential objective of the leasing transaction is to provide a dwelling suitable for habitation.’ Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, supra at 196-197. A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for.”

*See Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*,.raw_text: *See Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
*See Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*,.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain sanitary and habitable conditions breaches the implied warranty of habitability and evidences a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*See Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*,.support_reasoning: This concurring/dissenting opinion discusses an implied warranty of habitability and its relationship to statutory sanitary code duties, but it does not state that unsanitary or uninhabitable conditions constitute a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The author instead frames the landlord’s obligations in terms of implied contractual duties tied to code compliance and does not link those conditions to quiet enjoyment. Thus, while it supports an implied warranty theory based on habitability, it does not support the further proposition that such conditions evidence a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*See Boston Housing Auth. v. Hemingway*,.relevant_excerpt: “As the first step in the removal of the roadblock discussed above I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”}

*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain sanitary and habitable conditions breaches the implied warranty of habitability and evidences a violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion does recognize and award damages for a breach of the implied warranty of habitability, but it does not link that breach to, or analyze, any violation of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The court’s treatment of conditions focuses on code violations and rent abatement, and there is no discussion that the unsanitary or uninhabitable conditions themselves constitute or evidence a breach of quiet enjoyment. Thus, the case does not support the combined proposition as stated.
*Young v. Patukonis*, 24 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt:
“D. Breach of Warranty of Habitability.
Patukonis challenges the judge’s award of $625 in damages for the breach of warranty of habitability, maintaining that the judge failed both to use the ‘percentage reduction approach’ in calculating damages and to make specific findings regarding the extent of each violation. … The judge properly could have disregarded the minor code violations. … There is record support for the amount awarded.”

**M.G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A**.proposition: Under **M.G.L. c. 239, § 8A**, Plaintiff is entitled to assert this claim due to the existence of conditions materially affecting health, safety, or well-being.

**M.G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14**.proposition: Defendant’s persistent neglect and refusal to abate the rodent infestation constitute a “substantial interference” with Plaintiff’s use of the premises, thereby violating **M.G.L. c. 186, § 14**.

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 101\u2.proposition: Defendant’s persistent neglect and refusal to abate the rodent infestation constitute a “substantial interference” with Plaintiff’s use of the premises, thereby violating **M.G.L. c. 186, § 14**.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 101\u2.support_reasoning: The case is about repeated flooding and sewage, not rodent infestation, and the court’s § 14 analysis focuses on flooding as the interference with quiet enjoyment. While the opinion does hold that persistent unsanitary housing conditions (here, repeated flooding) that a landlord recklessly fails to abate can constitute interference with quiet enjoyment under M.G.L. c. 186, § 14, it does not specifically address rodents. Thus it supports a broader principle about serious, repeatedly unremedied sanitary violations being a substantial interference, but not the specific rodent‑infestation proposition as stated.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 101\u2.relevant_excerpt: “The water in Solomon’s apartment was a preventable situation, and one that Gem had a duty to prevent. See 105 Code Mass. Regs. 410.500; Crowell v. McCaffrey, 377 Mass. 443 (1979); Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973). The jury found in answer to a special question… that the water interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment of her apartment. Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

*Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847.proposition: The conduct described herein is comparable to that found actionable in *Al‑Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997), where persistent housing defects and landlord neglect constituted a breach of quiet enjoyment.
*Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847.support_reasoning: The opinion does not involve “persistent housing defects and landlord neglect” of the sort described in Simon, Cruz, or similar cases; it concerns lead paint liability and whether a statutory lead‑paint violation, by itself and without proof of negligent or knowing failure to act, constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment. The court squarely holds that strict liability under the lead paint statute alone is not enough and that at least negligent conduct with notice is required. Thus, the case limits when housing conditions amount to a breach of quiet enjoyment rather than finding the conditions here actionable under § 14.
*Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847.relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

*See Jablonski v. Clemons*, 60 Mass. App.raw_text: *See Jablonski v. Clemons*, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 473 (2004)
*See Jablonski v. Clemons*, 60 Mass. App.proposition: Additional Massachusetts authority confirms that even omissions—such as failing to make essential repairs or address infestations—can breach the covenant.
*See Jablonski v. Clemons*, 60 Mass. App.support_reasoning: The proposition is that Massachusetts authority recognizes that a landlord’s omissions—such as failure to make essential repairs or address infestations—can breach the covenant (of quiet enjoyment). Jablonski explicitly states that a landlord violates G.L. c. 186, § 14 when its “acts or omissions impair the value of the leased premises,” and applies that rule to the landlord’s failure over nine years to correct serious code-violating conditions (ventilation and longstanding ant infestation). The court holds that these unremedied defects required a finding of serious interference with the tenancy, thereby supporting the proposition.
*See Jablonski v. Clemons*, 60 Mass. App.relevant_excerpt:
“The implied covenant of quiet enjoyment guarantees tenants the right to be free from ‘serious’ interferences with their tenancies. See G. L. c. 186, § 14… A landlord violates G. L. c. 186, § 14, when its ‘acts or omissions impair the value of the leased premises.’ Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 789 (1994).

Here, the judge found that the landlord knowingly rented the premises in a defective condition and failed to correct the ventilation problem… for over nine years.… On these facts… we think that the judge was required to find a serious interference with the tenancy and substantial impairment of the character and value of the leased premises.”

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.proposition: Additional Massachusetts authority confirms that even omissions—such as failing to make essential repairs or address infestations—can breach the covenant.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states that a landlord’s breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment can arise not only from affirmative acts but also from what the landlord “failed to do” when the resulting condition is the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s conduct and within the landlord’s control. The court explicitly rejects any rigid distinction between nonfeasance (omissions) and malfeasance in this context. While the facts involve noise from a bar rather than repairs or infestations, the legal principle clearly encompasses omissions such as failing to act to correct serious conditions, supporting the proposition in general terms.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… To the extent that our opinions suggest a distinction between nonfeasance by the landlord, which has been said to create no liability … and malfeasance by the landlord, we decline to perpetuate that distinction where the landlord creates a situation and has the right to control the objectionable conditions.”

*Trustees of Cambridge Point Condominium.raw_text: *Trustees of Cambridge Point Condominium Trust v. Cambridge Point, LLC*, 478 Mass. 697 (2018).*
*Trustees of Cambridge Point Condominium.proposition: Additional Massachusetts authority confirms that even omissions—such as failing to make essential repairs or address infestations—can breach the covenant.

**105 C.M.R. 410.550**.proposition: The Department of Public Health’s Sanitary Code, **105 C.M.R. 410.550**, requires landlords to maintain residential units free from rodent infestation.

*See Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 41.raw_text: *See Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
*See Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 41.proposition: By his actions and inactions, Defendant has constructively interfered with Plaintiff’s right to quiet enjoyment of her home.
*See Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 41.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*See Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 41.support_reasoning: The case directly addresses a landlord’s liability for interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment based on failures to act. The SJC holds that a landlord can breach G. L. c. 186, § 14 when serious interference with the tenancy is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted to be done, and specifically states that if the housing authority failed to take measures to remove unlawful actors, it may be liable for breach of quiet enjoyment. That reasoning squarely supports a proposition that a defendant’s actions and inactions can constructively interfere with a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment.
*See Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 41.relevant_excerpt: “In analyzing whether there is a breach of the covenant, we examine the landlord’s conduct and not his intentions… a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … if the defendant has failed to take any measures… to remove unwelcome persons… and the presence of those persons seriously interferes with the tenancy, then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

*Lezberg v. Rogers*, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 1.proposition: By his actions and inactions, Defendant has constructively interfered with Plaintiff’s right to quiet enjoyment of her home.
*Lezberg v. Rogers*, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 1.support_reasoning: The case concerns allocation of responsibility for electric utility payments and the effect of a State Sanitary Code violation regarding separate metering; it does not address a tenant’s or landowner’s right to quiet enjoyment, constructive interference with that right, or any analogous doctrine. The holding is limited to barring the landlord’s recovery of utility charges because the lease provision was unlawful and cannot be enforced, and therefore does not provide authority for constructive interference with quiet enjoyment of a home.
*Lezberg v. Rogers*, 27 Mass. App. Ct. 1.relevant_excerpt: “Thus, it having been conclusively determined that the lease provision contravened the State Sanitary Code, the plaintiff may not recover from the defendant any part of the charges for electricity used for the period of the defendant’s occupancy. See Boston Housing Authy. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199 (1973). Cf. Leardi v. Brown, 394 Mass. 151, 156-157 (1985).”
